article-meta.aff: Department of Foot and Ankle Surgery, Western Pennsylvania Hospital, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (BTD, MJH, KRS)
Department of Pathology, Temple University School of Medicine, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (US)

author-notes.corresp: Karl R. Saltrick, DPM, Department of Foot and Ankle Surgery, Western Pennsylvania Hospital, 4800 Friendship Avenue, North Tower, First Floor, Pittsburgh, PA 15224; e-mail: ksaltric@wpahs.org.

abstract.p: Cutaneous myoepithelioma is a very rare, benign, subcutaneous and dermal tumor. It usually presents as a slow-growing and painless mass on the extremities. We report a case of cutaneous myoepithelioma that was located on the foot. A 68-yearold woman presented with a slowly growing pain-free mass on the right third toe measuring 0.8 × 0.7 × 0.4 cm3. We performed an elliptical excision, with histological and immunohistochemical analysis. The lesion showed dermis with cords of cytologically uniform ovoid cells with moderate amount of pale cytoplasm. No pleomorphism, mitotic activity, or necrosis was visualized. The tumor cells were positive for S-100 protein, epithelial membrane antigen and negative for smooth-muscle actin. From these findings, the tumor was diagnosed as a cutaneous myoepithelioma extending to the deep resection margin. To our knowledge, there are only 2 documented cases in the literature in English, and none have been reported in the foot and ankle literature.
Levels of Evidence: Therapeutic, Level IV, Case study

disp-quote.p: “The tumor typically presents on the extremities as a small, slow-growing, and pain-free mass.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cutaneous myoepithelioma is a rare, benign, subcutaneous and dermal tumor.1 The tumor typically presents on the extremities as a small, slow-growing, and pain-free mass.2 It is an exceptionally rare neoplasm. Only 38 have been reported in the literature in English, and only 2 have occurred on the foot and ankle.1-10 Cutaneous myoepthelioma is a relatively new diagnosis—it was originally reported by Kilpatrick et al11 in 1997. The median age of these patients is 40 years, with a male predominance.1-10 We report a case of a small, painless cutaneous myoepithelioma in a 68-year-old woman that was located on her right third toe.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 68-year-old woman presented with an insidious history of a firm, small, slowly growing, nontender mass on the dorsum of the right third toe. She denied any history of recent trauma. Her past medical history included hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hiatal hernia, anemia, osteoporosis, gout, and chronic back pain. Physical examination revealed a firm, nontender, nonpulsatile, nonmotile mass on the dorsal aspect of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the right third toe. The lesion measured 0.8 cm in length by 0.7 cm in width by 0.4 cm in height. Dermatologically, there were 2 healed scars over the fourth and fifth toes from a prior hammer toe correction, with no evidence of hypertrophic scar or keloid formation. There were no other inflammatory findings or breaks in the integument. She had palpable pulses with protective sensation intact. There were no gross deformities noted in the right lower extremity. Muscle strength and joint range of motion were within the accepted parameters. Preoperative laboratory tests, including a complete blood count with differential and basic metabolic profile, were within normal limits.

The lesion was surgically removed in excisional fashion through converging elliptical incisions and sent to pathology. Histologically, the lesion showed dermis with cords of cytologically uniform ovoid cells, with a moderate amount of pale cytoplasm. No pleomorphism, mitotic activity, or necrosis was visualized. Immunohistochemical testing revealed that the cells were positive for S-100 protein, epithelial membrane antigen and negative for smooth-muscle actin among others. The specimen was given a diagnosis of a cutaneous myoepithelioma extending to the deep resected margin. Her postoperative course was uneventful. She was informed that the margins were not clear of the tumor, and local recurrence was a possibility. There has been no recurrence of the lesion 5 years after excision.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Myoepithelial cells are specific contractile cells located in the respiratory tract, breast tissue, salivary glands, and the skin.9 Myoepitheliomas are benign and malignant neoplams of myoepithelial cells and have been found most commonly in the salivary glands.12-15 Extrasalivary examples include the breast, lung, larynx, retroperitoneum, and the skin.4,11,16-18 The first cutaneous myoepithelioma was identified in 1997.1 There have only been 38 cases of cutaneous myoepithelioma and 4 cases of cutaneous myoepithelial carcinoma reported in the literature in English to date.1-10 There have only been 2 cases of cutaneous myoepithelioma and 1 case of cutaneous myoepithelial carcinoma described in the foot and ankle.6,7 This report appears to be the third case of a cutaneous myoepithelioma occurring on the foot.

Cutaneous myoepithelioma appears clinically as a painless cutaneous nodule that gradually expands. A differential diagnosis could include epithelioid benign fibrous histiocytoma (dermatofibroma) and melanocytic tumors (eg, Spitz nevus).19 The most common location is found on the extremities. Men are affected more than women. The median age for all cutaneous myoepitheliomas reported is 40 years, with the median age for all cutaneous myoepithelial carcinomas reported at 56 years. The 2 cases of cutaneous myoepithelioma occurring on the foot were both in women aged 25 and 71 years old. Interestingly, the only case of cutaneous myoepithelial carcinoma was in a 14-year-old girl and was located on the great toe.6,7 The case reported here consisted of a slow-growing tumor of many years’ duration on a 68-year-old woman.

Histopathological evaluation of cutaneous myoepithelioma typically reveals well-delineated borders devoid of capsule and lacking invasion into the epidermis.7 They have no tubular or ductal differentiation but may show a lobulated or solid configuration. Plasmacytoid, epithelioid, spindled, or ovoid myoepithelial cells may also be visualized.4 The cytoplasm is scantly eosinophilic, with small amounts of surrounding stroma.2 The neoplasm we report displayed dermis with cords of cytologically uniform ovoid cells with a moderate amount of pale cytoplasm. No pleomorphisms, mitotic activity, or necrosis were visualized. However, there were no clear margins because the tumor extended the deep margins of the resection (Figure 1).

caption.p: Photomicrograph With Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Displaying Dermis With Cords of Cytologically Uniform Ovoid Cells With Moderate Amount of Pale Cytoplasm. No Pleomorphisms, Mitotic Activity, or Necrosis Was Visualized.

sec.p: Immunohistochemical examination of cutaneous myoepithelioma is typically reactive to actin, S-100 protein, epithelial membrane antigen, and cytokeratin. The expression of the myoid-specific marker desmin is regularly absent.19 Moreover, in the 2 cutaneous myoepitheliomas reported on the foot, both were immunopositive for S-100 protein and showed mild cytological atypia.6,7 The tumor cells in this case were positive for S-100 protein (Figure 2), epithelial membrane antigen (Figure 3) and negative for smooth-muscle actin (Figure 4), AE1/AE3, CAM5.2, CD31, CD34, HMB-45, and Melan-A.

caption.p: Photomicrograph of Epithelial Membrane Antigen–Positive Cells.

sec.p: An authoritative criterion for a diagnosis of cutaneous myoepithelial carcinoma has yet to be established. However, it is suggested that the presence of neoplasms containing moderate to severe cytological atypicality may be termed myoepithelial cutaneous carcinomas.20 Metastasis and recurrence have also been associated with an increased mitotic index.6,21 Furthermore, the 1 cutaneous myoepithelial carcinoma reported in the literature demonstrated severe atypia with a high amount of mitotic activity and invasion into the periostium.6 In the case described in this report, the cells were uniform with a moderate amount of pale cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei. Because there were no pleomorphisms, mitotic activity, or necrosis, it was concluded that this tumor was benign.

The gold standard for treatment in the majority of the 38 cases of cutaneous myoepitheliomas was total local excision with clear margins.1,2 Rarely, local recurrence and metastases to lymph nodes has been documented.6 No deaths have ever been acknowledged from this neoplasm. Mohs micrographic surgery has been proposed and used for recurrent and/or aggressive neoplasms.19 Both the cutaneous myoepitheliomas occurring on the foot were primarily excised with wide margins. One recurred 2 years later and was re-excised, with no recurrence at 7 years’ follow-up. The 1 case of cutaneous myoepithelial carcinoma on the great toe was treated with primary amputation with no recurrence.6 The lesion in this case was primarily excised with the intention of obtaining wide margins. This was not possible because the tumor extended to the deep margins of the excised mass. The tumor was diagnosed as benign, and the patient elected to monitor the area and if there was recurrence to return immediately. A 5-year follow-up revealed no recurrence of the lesion.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In summary, cutaneous myoepithelioma is a rare, painless, subcutaneous and dermal neoplasm that has an insidious course with slow growth. This lesion can develop in the young or the old but most often around midlife. They are most commonly located on an extremity but other sites have been reported. Although the majority of cutaneous myoepitheliomas are benign, they still have the possibility for local recurrence and metastasis. The gold standard for treatment of this rare tumor is total excision with pathological confirmation of clear margins.
